Award.AwardTitle: A Novel Non-Contact Technique for Dynamic Loading of Thin Film Materials Using Finite Amplitude Mechanical Stress Waves

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project seeks to develop a new laser based technique for the generation of finite amplitude surface acoustic stress waves. The proposed technique would facilitate the understanding of the nonlinear elastic response of thin film materials at ultrasonic frequencies. This development would lead to quantitative measurement of various nonlinear elastic properties including; decohesion and fracture strength of thin film interfaces, using nonlinear elastic stress waves. The technique uses a laser source focused to line on a sample surface to generate plane surface acoustic stress waves through the thermoelastic effect. The laser generated stress waves are monitored using a path stabilized Michelson interferometer. By scanning the laser line source on the sample surface at the phase velocity of the surface wave, the stress wave amplitude is amplified continuously with distance. The technique would enable loading thin film materials with strain amplitudes of the order of 0.01 with strain rates greater than one million per second. The contact-free nature of the technique allows for accurate modeling of the processes of stress wave generation and propagation, leading to reliable extraction of thin film material properties.

If the project is successful, the proposed technique would enable the quantitative assessment of the mechanical reliability and stability of film based small scale structures including MEMS and NEMS devices. These properties are critical to their successful integration into more complex microelectronic devices. Furthermore, the project is integrated with various educational activities including, graduate course enrichment, graduate student training, and outreach activities to high school students.

ProgramReference.Text: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF funded projected enabled the exploration of pulsed laser based methods for generation of high amplitude surface acoustic waves. These waves travel near the surface of a solid, retaining their elastic energy within a penetration depth of a wavelength below the surface. Consequently, the properties and characteristics of the surface acoustic waves are strongly sensitive to near surface elastic properties and interfaces. In this project, we explored surface acoustic waves for impulsive fracture and delamination of thin films, using waves with dynamic elastic strains of up to 10^-3. The use of surface acoustic waves allowed for fast loading of the sample, thus elimination energy loss mechanisms due to plasticity. A combination of a new experimental approach and modeling schemes were developed to study the stress field of the laser generated stress waves.  The modeling effort was also extended to materials with depth dependent elastic properties. These aspects of the work can be used for measurement of the work of adhesion in thin films and to study the dependence of this property of loading rates. Utimately, the use of lasers to seed local thin film delamination is attractive, because it can enable controlled patterning of delamination patterns including thin film blisters and ribbons, and quantitative characterization of interfacial properties.


Last Modified: 03/03/2016
Modified by: Oluwaseyi Balogun

The use of surface acoustic waves allowed for fast loading of the sample, thus elimination energy loss mechanisms due to plasticity. A combination of a new experimental approach and modeling schemes were developed to study the stress field of the laser generated stress waves.
